did.unittitle: Louis J. Budd Papers and compilation of Mark Twain Resources, 1980-2008, undated
did.abstract: The bulk of the papers are comprised of Lou Budd’s collection of Mark Twain caricatures, interviews and reviews. Correspondence and materials related to his tenure as trustee at the Mark Twain Memorial for the years 1992-1999 are the extent of materials in the collection related to Budd’s professional life. The collection contains the manuscript and research for one scholarly article, Seeing Double Can be Twice as Clear: Mark Twain’s Impersonators.

repository.corpname: Mark Twain Archive, Gannett-Tripp Library, Elmira College, Elmira, N.Y.

bioghist.p: Budd was born August 26, 1921 in St. Louis, Missouri, the last of three children in his family. His father Vincent Budrewicz, a Polish immigrant from Lithuania, had served in the army of Czarist Russia.

When discharged as a reservist, Vincent Budrewicz emigrated, arriving in America in 1910. Louis's mother Zofia Kajszo, a devout Catholic, emigrated from Lithuania to America in 1911. In 1930 Vincent Budrewicz was a laborer in a shoe factory and his wife Zofia worked at a bakery a half a block from the family home. Following the lead of his older brother, Louis would later change his surname to Budd.

After graduating from high school at age fifteen, Budd attended the University of Missouri majoring in English literature and was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. Budd received his B.A. there in 1941 and his M.A. in 1942.

After serving in World War II, in 1945 he married Isabelle Amelia Marx-it was a marriage that produced two children and lasted more than 60 years, until her death in 2006. Budd entered the University of Wisconsin under the GI Bill and obtained his Ph.D. in American literature in 1949. Budd's doctoral thesis was titled "William Dean Howells's Relations with Political Parties."

From 1949 to 1952, Budd taught at the University of Kentucky at Lexington. In 1952 he relocated to Duke University and remained with Duke until his retirement. Budd's first book titled "Mark Twain: Social Philosopher" was published by Indiana University Press in 1962. The book traced the development of Mark Twain's social commitments and changing political attitudes.
Budd received a Guggenheim Fellowship in 1965. He lectured in India in May 1966 as a Fulbright scholar and returned to lecture in India again in October and November of 1972.

From 1968-70 he chaired the Afro-American Studies program at Duke. In 1973 he became chairman of the English department and served in that capacity until 1979. In June of 1978 Budd traveled to the University of Damascus as a visiting lecturer. He was awarded a NEH Senior Fellowship in 1979-80. In 1979 he became managing editor of the journal American Literature. Budd became a prolific editor with Duke University Press, publishing numerous literary collections taken from back issues of American Literature.
He served on editorial and advisory boards of numerous publications including Studies in American Humor, South Atlantic Review, Mississippi Studies in English, and American Literary Realism.

Throughout his career, Budd used his archival research skills to compile data on Mark Twain. In 1983, Budd published "Our Mark Twain: The Making of His Public Personality," which included rare caricatures and cartoons of Twain gathered from scarce 19th century publications.
Budd was the recipient of numerous awards for outstanding scholarship, including several honorary degrees. In 1991 Budd received one of the first Mark Twain Circle Awards.

Budd formally retired from Duke University in 1991 although he continued to teach there until 1996. In 1992 he arranged and annotated a two-volume edition "Mark Twain: Collected Tales, Sketches, Speeches, & Essays" for Library of America. In 1999 Budd published "Mark Twain: The Contemporary Reviews" with Cambridge University Press which provided hard-to- obtain texts of early magazine and newspaper reviews of Mark Twain's works. In 2005 he and Peter Messent co-edited "A Companion to Mark Twain."

scopecontent.p: The collection is primarily a compilation of resources compiled by Lou Budd regarding Mark Twain caricatures, interviews and reviews. The caricatures, interviews and reviews are secondary sources consisting of reproductions, transcriptions, negatives and prints.

The collection contains research and manuscript drafts for one article titled, “Seeing Double Can Be Twice as Clear: Mark Twain Impersonators.” Budd’s affiliation with the Mark Twain Memorial as Trustee is represented in the collection through board minutes, agendas and correspondence, including news clippings, articles and promotional materials regarding Mark Twain’s Hartford house.
Absent from the collection are personal papers or documents pertinent to Lou Budd’s scholarship.

note.p: This sub-series contains no works by Lou Budd and is primarily comprised of proposals for Mark Twain related programming, particularly for television, that were sent to Budd. The scripts for Samuel Clemens and Mark Twain a film project by Sandra Bradley and Mark Twain and Mark Twain and the Laughing River by Jim Post are the only materials in this sub-series that contain correspondence whereby Budd offers an opinion on the work. All other files only contain the article and/or project proposal. This series is organized alphabetically by title.

SERIES 2: CARICATURES

note.p:
The series primarily consists of reproductions, negatives and prints of Mark Twain caricatures. Louis Budd states in a letter to the National Portrait Gallery in 1989, “For some years I have
been gathering caricatures of Mark Twain, especially those done during his lifetime. Eventually, of course, I plan some kind of publication though I am still primarily concerned with gathering and analyzing the materials” (Box 2 Folder 182). Caricatures from later dates, though present, are not as thoroughly documented.

The collection contains few original materials and is almost exclusively comprised of prints and negatives of reproductions. Dates from the limited correspondence and from Budd’s online resources, including the statement above, indicate Budd was actively collecting caricatures for an eventual publication up until his death in 2006. The collection is primarily focused on caricatures created in Twain’s own time; caricatures from later dates, though present, are not as thoroughly documented. This series represents Budd’s twenty plus year research commitment to collecting Mark Twain caricatures.

The collection of Mark Twain caricatures remains in original order, primarily organized by date of publication (the first three folders are miscellaneous). Original folder headings are used whenever possible.

New York SUN -- "Mark Twain Home Again/He Went Away with a Load of Debt Which He Voluntarily Assumed, and Has Paid It all Off--He Will Not Lecture Again, He Says, Unless He Is Compelled To" -- "Clemens announces his anti-imperialism, discusses paying off his creditors"

New York Tribune -- "Mark Twain Home/Arrives in Minnehaha with Wife and Daughters" -- "One of better versions, both for substance and coherence; Clemens discusses current politics, his literary plans, and his immediate future, and reviews his travels since 1891"

New York World -- "Mark Twain Home Again Hale and Happy at 65/After Nine Years Abroad, He Declares That He Will Break Both Legs, So That He Cannot Leave America Again--To Winter in New York" -- "Shorter, much less political than other interviews"
New York Mail and Express -- "Mark Twain Talks/Says His Chief Desire Is Not to Be Told to Move On" -- "Clemens says most about being a mugwump"

New York Times -- "Mark Twain Home Again/Talks Freely of His Travels, His Experiences, and His Triumphs--In the Best of Health" -- "Clemens has much to say on politics and gives details of his visit to Jameson Raiders"

New York World -- "My Impressions of America/And Kate Carew's Impressions of the Great Humorist/An Interview in Which He Refuses to Be Interviewed/Eluding the Subject Proposed, He Talks About Almost Everything Else, Including Truth, Waiters, Early breakfasts, Wisdom and Noise" -- Clemens was submitting to being sketched rather than interviewed and said little of consequence"
New York World -- "Wouldn't Work 30 Minutes for 500 Dollars/Declares That He Only Does Work When It Is an Absolute Necessity" -- "Clemens declines to cover a Bryan mass meeting for the WORLD"
Hartford Current -- "What Mr. Clemens Said/His Grief at News of Mr. Warner's Death/Old Days Recalled/Humorist's Plans" -- "Clemens also praises Plasmon and asks about Connecticut politics"

New York Journal and Advertiser -- "A Day with Mark Twain/Funniest Man in the World/Pictorially Told by Vivid Snap Shots at America's Famous Humorist" -- "Clemens explains why he has decided to shun serious interviews; comments on unrelated matters, with most about his visit to the jail in Pretoria (possibly a pastiche of other interviews)"

New York World -- "Sure Mark Twain is in a Crooked Game/Housekeeper who did No. 14 East on Tenth Street Annoyed by Inquiries for Him/He's at No. 14 West" -- "Clemens, while commenting on a housekeeper who did not recognize either of his names, insists that he cannot afford to talk to the press free of charge"
New York World -- "Mark Twain at Football Game" -- "Clemens attends Yale-Princeton game and makes a few spectator's remarks"

New York Times Sun, Tribune, World -- "Mark Twain is Avenged/One False/Cabby Learns the Power of His Wrath" -- "Not an interview but a long and interesting report of Clemens appearing in magistrate's court in New York City to press a complaint against a cabman who had overcharged his housekeeper"
New York Herald -- "Mark Twain in His New York Den" -- "A combination feature-story interview, with many photographs; Clemens comments mostly on persons appealing for money criticizes grand opera"
New York Times -- "Mark Twain Hazing/Calls West Point Cadets Who Indulge in It Cowards" -- "Clemens speaks out briefly against hazing and adds a reminiscence about his boyhood fights"

New York Journal and Advertiser, New York Times -- "Mark Twain/Expert on Trade Marks/Has Fun/Says They Won't Let Me talk, He Testifies in a Suit of Rudyard Kipling's about Copyright" -- "Clemens answers some questions on copyrights as an expert, in a hearing before a United States Commissioner"
New York World -- "Mark Twain in the Woods" -- "Clemens at Lake Saranac, refuses to be quoted on any serious subject; much description and photographs of his summer house"
New York Journal and Advertiser -- "Mark Twain Offers to Vote for Satin"
New York SUN, New York Journal -- "Mark Twain will Warmly Great Robbers/Riverdale Burglar-Ridden"
New York Herald, Baltimore SUN -- "Sh-hhh Says Mark Twain"

New York Tribune , New York SUN -- "Mark Twain Would Be a Bill Poster" -- "Actually a news story, quite possibly planted; Clemens appears at anti-Tammany headquarters and wants to go out pasting up political posters; he jeers at Tammany tactics and candidates"

San Francisco Examiner -- "Mark Twain Says it's All Rubbish/College Education is Not Essential to the Making of a Gentleman" -- "Actually a statement or press release; Clemens rejects view that the new millionaires, if they have not been to college, can be gentlemen"

Charleston Sunday News -- "Tom Reed and Mark Twain/Mark Twain in Town/ Mark Twain with a Julep" -- "No direct quotation but extensive summary on Mark Twain's remark: praise for Charleston Exploration"

Saint Louis Post-Dispatch -- "Mark Twain Here as Saint Louis' Guest for the First Time Since 1861" -- "Long, loose item; Clemens comments on Bret Harte and on piloting career, recalls in detail the Punch, Brothers, Punch jingle and the heap pipe presented to him in Virginia City"
Saint Louis Star -- "Mark Twain Laughs in Grain Pits" -- "Clemens speaks at Merchants Exchange, then chats in hotel lobby about his health and laziness and discusses river traffic with Horace Bixby"
Saint Louis Post-Dispatch -- "Mark Twain's Visit to Hannibal" -- "Part feature story, part interview; Clemens reminisces about old friends on the river and other Missourians"

Saint Louis Republic -- "Mark Twain Comes Back to Missouri/Affection of Old Friends Brings Mark Twain to Tears/Reminiscences of Humorist/Mark Twain Visits His Old Sweetheart/Mark Twain Guest of President Jesse/Mark Twain's Reunion/Mark Twain at Pilot Wheel; Bids Farewell to Mississippi

Saint Louis Post-Dispatch -- "Mark Twain Takes a Drive/Tom Sawyer Character in Hannibal" -- "Clemens comments to old acquaintances and reminisces casually; comments on local traditions about who were the originals for some of his characters"

Saint Louis Post-Dispatch -- "Mark Twain Takes a Drive/Tom Sawyer Character in Hannibal" -- "Clemens comments to old acquaintances and reminisces casually; comments on local traditions about who were the originals for some of his characters"

Hannibal Morning Journal -- "Mark Twain Going Home" -- "Mostly news story but summarizes a 30 minute conversation when the reporter found Mark Twain lying in bed puffing away on a black cigar and with a book in his hand"
Saint Louis Star, Saint Louis Globe-Democrat -- "Mark Twain at Wheel Again" -- "Clemens chats casually about river traffic, past and present

Saint Louis Post-Dispatch -- Mark Twain at Smoke Talk/Twain at Helm of Harbor Book/Mark Twain's Visit Over" -- "Clemens comments casually on events of current visit, and his taste in cigars, and he tells an anecdote about his and W.D. Howells' interest in a pretty pedestrian"
The Hannibal Evening Courier-Post -- "Mark Twain"
Cassell's Magazine -- "A Day with Mark Twain" -- "Not identical with piece in New York World, 21 July 1901, but based on same visit; really a feature story with no quotations of consequence"
New York World -- "My First Vacation and My Last" -- "Free ranging item; some yarn-spinning reminiscences; Clemens mentions his work on a new novel"

New York Evening Journal -- "Mark Twain: Study of an American Who Has Interested and Amused 50,000,000 People by His Wit/Mark Twain: His Wit and Humor" -- "Reporter comes along with Homer Davenport, for a full page spread of words and pictures; Mark Twain makes some interesting comments about fossils and about Monte Carlo"

New York World -- "Men of To-Day Who Make the World Laugh" -- "Mark Twain repudiates the interview that accompanied the Homer Davenport visit of December 1902; that is, he says he had not expected a report on the conversation to appear; refuses to be interviewed, commenting at some length on idea that writers, unlike politicians, should be paid for interviews, which use up their stock in trade"
New York Herald -- "Mark Twain's Door Open to Burglars" -- "Frothy comment on his respect for successful burglars"
New York Herald -- "Mark Twain on the Yacht Races" -- "Actually written by Clemens; he clowns about his knowledge of yachting and about how he has adapted his style to being paid by the word"

New York Evening Journal -- "Mark Twain Off Shooting Shafts of Humor" -- "By far the longest of the items for this occasion; reporter picked up Mark Twain at the hotel and stayed close; Mark Twain talks about Dowie and also about Henry Lucy--OBITUARY scheme; also comments on the comparison of him to Aristophanes and Rabelais"
New York Herald, SUN, Times, Review -- "Mark Twain Makes Some Parting Remarks/Comments on Aristophanes, Rabelais, Dowse, and Mrs. Eddy"

Ladies Home Journal -- "Mark Twain's Pictures/Three Famous Authors" -- "Mark Twain, W.D. Howells, and Henry Van Dyke; three photos of Mark Twain with a sentence or two commentary each; two of the photos get further, quoted commentary, photos taken at Quarry Farm; not really an interview but list because of R. Willis comment""
Courier Della Sera -- "Italian Accounts of Mark Twain Aboard and at Home: An Interview and a Visit"
Metropolitan Magazine -- "An Interview with Mark Twain" -- "Author is very obtrusive and indeed features her own opinions and anecdotes; item is finally of no consequence"
The Sketch -- "Mark Twain on the Law of Copyright" -- "Clemens also comments, briefly, on Italians, Mary Baker Eddy, and mass opinion"
New York Times -- "Mark Twain to Reform the Language of Italy" -- "A very coherent; covers Italy and Italian, Clemens's reading"
New York Times -- "A Talk with Mark Twain's Cat/The Owner Himself Being Invisible" -- "Reporter fails to get to see Clemens"
Boston Herald -- "The Same Old Mark Twain" -- "Long and coherent; but stresses copyright and color of Mark Twain's personality while recording same main subjects as other accounts"

Boston Globe -- "In Genial Mood/Mark Twain Talks on Various Topics" -- "Long, coherent item; main subjects are copyright, political and business corruption in United States, Imperialism in the Congo and South Africa, and Czarist Tyranny"

Boston Evening Transcript -- "Mark Twain Talks on 'Graft'" -- "After remarks on copyright and imperialism in South Africa, Clemens talks at length about current corruption and places its source in post-bellum speculation"
Boston Journal -- "Mark Twain, Between Puffs, Talks Some" -- "Relaxed commentary by Clemens on copyright law, atrocities in the Congo, tyranny in czarist Russia, and the insurance scandal"

Hartford Courant -- "Mark Twain at 70/He discusses Summer Homes and His Work" -- "Clemens wrote out the quoted parts; he details his liking for Dublin, New Hampshire, as a summer retreat and briefly mentions what pieces of writing he has worked on lately"
New York World -- "Mark Twain on Summer Homes" -- "Quoted parts identical with Hartford Courant of 25 November and New York American and Journal of 26 November"

New York World Sunday Magazine -- "What I am Thankful For" -- "Prearranged interview; long; dependable; Clemens discusses his dyspepsia, his habit of non-exercise, his self-editing, and (briefly) the use of humor; then launches into long, rehearsed diatribe against Leopold"

New York Times -- "Mark Twain: A Humorist's Confession/On the Eve of His 70th Birth Anniversary, He Admits He Never Did a Day's Work" -- "Clemens discusses play v. work, his reputation and seriousness as a humorist, and national differences in humor"

Seattle (Washington) Star -- "Samuel L. Clemens Interviews the Great Humorist, Mark Twain" -- "Clemens humorously discusses photographs and other representations of himself, wishes them to be kinder; plugs Peter Pan"
New York Herald -- "Samuel Clemens's in Washington, D.C./Congress Admires Mark Twain's Hair"
New York Herald -- "Mark Twain in Moving Pictures" -- "Comic photographs of Clemens with some captions presumably suggested by him"
Hartford Courant -- "Mark Twain Pays Tribute to Servant" -- "Series of laudatory remarks about the deceased"
New York Herald -- "Mark Twain Too Lazy for a United States Senator" -- "Clemens humorously rejects notion that he might be a senator; feels he would not be taken seriously"

New York American and Journal -- "Huckleberry Finn's End Disappoints Mark Twain" -- "Clemens comments quizzically on the many persons over the years who have claimed to be the models for Tom and Huck"

New York SUN, Tribune, World -- "Mark Twain on Gorky Affair/Gorky Visit/Hotels Turn Gorky Away" -- "In part or whole, probably written answers by Clemens to reporters' questions about Maxim Gorky scandal"

New York Times and Tribune -- "Mark Twain Appeal for San Francisco/Mark Twain's Memories of the City" -- "After appeal from platform for aid to victims of San Francisco earthquake, Clemens gives reporters an anecdote about a small quake he once experienced"

New York Evening Journal -- "Mark Twain Helps to Open the Day and Night Bank in NYC" -- "Mark Twain is among those who make deposits in the new Day and Night Bank, Mark Twain said he could deposit money there if he felt like it, but he decided not to do it for fear of exciting the envy of other authors. Mark Twain said it was a fine sign of prosperity when the town had to keep a bank going night and day"

Human Life -- "Mark Twain Dean of Our Humorists" -- "Evidently talked with Clemens lately, when he returned for funeral of Patrick McAleer; has a few brief quoted comments; also has some local anecdotes and reminiscence of his own"
Boston Sunday Post -- "Walks Around the Hudson"

The Chattanooga Times -- "Polk Miller's Visit to Mark Twain" -- "Entertainer famous for his Old Times Down South program reports recent session of reminiscence with Clemens about antebellum and plantation days"
New York American -- "Twain Would Like to Dress Like Adam" -- "Clemens jokes at length about men's clothing and fashions"
New York Times -- "An Advocate of Dress Reform" -- "Clemens drolls on at length about clothing"
Washington (D.C.) Post -- "Twain's Fancy Suit"

Washington Evening Star, Washington Herald -- 'Mark Twain in White/Twain Awes Capitol" -- "Much joking about clothes; Clemens is sardonic about a library banning 'Eve's Diary'; brief comment on several current political matters; firm plea for renewal of copyrights"
New York SUN, Tribune, World, Herald -- "Dress Uniform and Copyright"

New York Times -- "Twain's Plan to Beat Copyright Law" -- "Solid interesting item, though Clemens must have stipulated there be no quoting; gives details of his intention to renew in effect the copyright of his books by adding relevant portions of autobiography to them"
Washington (D.C.) Post -- "Heard at the Capitol" -- "Clemens offers departing judgments on how the fight for extending the term of copyright should be conducted"

New York World -- "Mark Twain Actually in Earnest" -- "A statement obtained by Ervin Justice; Clemens feels that his white suit and his joking detracted from the serious point of his visit to Washington; argues against 42-year limit for copyright"
New York Times -- "Twain and the Telephone" -- "Clemens praises the telharmonium and reminisces about his early use of the telephone and his habit of using profanity"
New York American, Herald, Times, Tribune, World: Bermuda Colonist -- "New Year’s Eve Party" -- "Comments on New York State politics"
New York Herald, New York Tribune, New York Times -- "Mark Twain Back from Bermuda"
New York Times -- "For the Longfellow Century/Tributes to Poet by Men of Letters/Mark Twain Tells of His Visits" -- "Clemens recalls contacts with him in 1870s"
New York Herald -- "Mark Twain Sails South" -- "Brief; Clemens gives humorous reasons for going to Bermuda"

New York Times -- "Mark Twain's Wanderings at an End" -- "Long item; mostly history by the reporter but has some quotation; Mark Twain comments on some of his homes briefly; more unimportant, amends three or four famous anecdotes about him"

Elmira Daily Advertiser -- "Mark Twain in Elmira" -- "Not a substantial item; Clemens resists being interviewed but finally relents to help out cub reporter; then he gives a boost to the progress for Elmira talk going around and especially to the organ manufacturing company"

New York American -- "Mark Twain is Going to be a Buccaneer" -- "Interesting item; Mark Twain defends his plan to go down to Jamestown for a naval review, along with Rogers; comments cynically on the Peace Congress just completed at Carnegie Hall, i.e., is not very sanguine about the prospects for peace and pacifism"
Norfolk Ledger-Dispatch -- "Marooned Mark Twain" -- "Clemens explains why he is waiting to go back to New York City alone by yacht rather than by train"
New York American, SUN, Times, Tribune, World -- "Twain Hesitates to Admit He's Dead" -- "Clemens chaffs about report that he has been drown at sea"

Baltimore American -- "Mark Twain at Annapolis/Mark Twain an Honored Guest" -- "Clemens chatted ten minutes between trains about recent report he had drowned, praised Southern cooking, joked about wearing ribbon of Legion of Honor"

Baltimore News -- "Mark Twain Tells His Literary Secret and Many Other Things" -- "Fine item; long and much quotation; on his autobiography in progress; on seriousness of his work; on paying off the Webster debt; on his five works that he will leave unfinished; long attack on German, American, and British imperialism"

Baltimore SUN -- "Mark Twain in Clover" -- "Reporters on hand at railroad station; long, useful item; mixture of superficiality and comments on purchase of Philippine Islands, the Belgian Congo, his autobiography, disfranchising the Negara, and his white suit"

Baltimore American -- "As Mark Twain Watched the Drill" -- "Reporter followed Clemens around and got his opinions on interviewing, on his smoking, on mugwumps, and on Peace Congress; technically not an interview but worthwhile and appropriate"

Baltimore SUN, New York Tribune -- "Mark Twain Departs/Mark Twain at Annapolis" -- "Clemens comments on his background as a journalist, how characters such as Huck and Tom are created, 'Eve's Diary', and an admitting poem about his serious side"
New York Times -- "Mighty Mark Twain Over-Awes Marines" -- "Datelined Annapolis; probably report of a lecture; filled with familiar anecdotes"

New York American -- "Mark Twain Tells the Secrets of Novelists" -- "Clemens contends that books and characters tend to find their own line of development once the author has conceived them and started to write"

New York American, Times -- "Mark Twain Sails/Shiest Man Aboard/Humorist Takes His Last Trip to London from this Sphere" -- "Clemens discusses the autobiography he is writing but will hold back from publication; chats at length about his autobiography, which will create a sensation when it is eventually published after his death"
London Evening News -- "Arrival of Mark Twain/Collecting Hints for His Funeral Procession" -- "Clemens chaffs a great deal on minor matters"
Westminster Gazette -- "Mark Twain in London"
London Daily Chronicle -- "Mark Twain/Mr. Clemens's Arrives in England" -- "Clemens jokes about many subjects including himself"
London -- "G.B.S. and Mark Twain: First Greeting of Two Great Men/Mark Twain in London/Mark Twain Arrives from America/The American Humorist in London"

London Daily Express -- "Mark Twain in London/Wants Hints for his Funeral from Oxford Pageant/A Bright Lad" -- Interviewer lists twelve subjects that Clemens touched on and then mentions others, especially the funeral"
London Daily Mail -- "Edgar Wallace/Mark Twain in London" -- "Attempts jocosity in Clemens's vein of humor about his funeral, his use of Italian, and his white suits"
London Daily Mirror -- "Mark Twain Reaches England" -- "Clemens jokes about his funeral and Kipling"

London Morning Leader -- "Mark Twain an the Secrets of Youth/In England to Receive Oxford Honor/Chaffs Interview and Himself" -- "Much joking , especially about his funeral, his ancestry, and his white suits"

Manchester Dispatch -- "Mark Twain's Quest/Looking for Ideas for His Funerals/Meeting with G.B.S." -- "May be by W.B. Northrop; nothing unusual in the content; relative to the many other accounts of the occasion
New York SUN and New York Times, Chicago Inter-Ocean -- "Mark Twain Tells Sea Tales" -- "Clemens jokes in high spirits about the voyage over to England"

New York Herald, World, Saint Louis Globe-Democrat -- "Mark Twain in London/Meets Mr. Bernard Shaw" -- "Mark Twain jokes with G.B. Shaw and winks at reporters; then comically outlines his daily routine"
London Evening News -- "Mark Twain at Windsor/To Be One of the Guests of the King" -- "Clemens gives anecdote about the King; outlines his social schedule"
London Daily Mail -- E.W. "Mark Twain's Plans/To Meet the King To-Morrow" -- "Summary of a drifting conversation with banquets and Clemens's funeral as the uppermost subjects"

New York American -- "Mark Twain Again Meets His Former Chum Edward/Renew Acquaintance with the King, Which He Started Years Ago on a Bus" -- "Clemens reminisces about meeting King Edward ten years ago at Hamburg; makes statement after the garden party at Windsor"
London -- "Mark Twain's Statement in Windsor Garden Party"
London Evening News -- "Mark's 'Mots'/Plans and Patents a Joke for the 'Punch' Dinner" -- "No direct quotations; Clemens muses about his immediate engagements"
London Leader -- "Mark Twain Meets King Edward/And Describes the Royal Garden Party" -- "Clemens jokes about heaven, bright clothes, napping, and his white bathrobe"
London Daily News -- "Oxford Pageant/What Mark Twain Thought" -- "Clemens praises the pageants"

New York Times -- "Mark Twain Living Up to His Degree/Honor Conferred upon Him/By Oxford Seems to Have Sobered Him/Is Excessively Solemn/Says England's Welcome Has Impressed Him Greatly--Calls Ceremony at Oxford Beautiful" -- "Clemens is on these good behavior"

New York SUN -- "Mark Twain for Penny Post" -- "A long, genuine item that Clemens probably planned for; is for lower international postal rates; introduces humorous, probably fanciful autobiography about how he used to embezzle money that father gave him for stamps"
London Daily Chronicle -- "Mark Twain/Confession Made by His Own Fireside"
London Daily News -- "Sleepy, But Happy/Mark Twain's Regretful Farewell" -- "Mark Twain makes

New York World, New York Times -- "Mark Twain Moved to Postpone Funeral/Younger Now By 7 Years, He Says, and Changes Mind about Dying" -- "Clemens briefly waxes enthusiastic about his current visit to England"
London Morning Leader, London Tribune -- "Two Mark Twains/One of them Leave England/Mark Twain's Farewell"

New York Evening World -- "English Know a Joke/Mark Twain's Wireless Message from the Sea/Reports that His Ship Tore Off the Bowsprit of an Unknown Bark in the Fog" -- "Clemens comments briefly on a number of topics including the British sense of humor"
New York American -- "Twain Home with English Jokes at 30 Cents a Word" -- "Much chaffing about the Ascot cup; Clemens defends British sense of humor"
New York Herald -- "Dr. Mark Twain, Pelted, Home Again" -- "Clemens jokes about his visit to England and the return voyage"
New York SUN -- "Mark Twain Comes in White" -- "Clemens comments on recent stories about his English visit; chaffs about old age and his new rate for 'stories and jokes'"
New York Times -- "Mark Twain Home in Good Humor"
New York Tribune -- "Twain Glad He's Back" -- "Somewhat fewer quotations
New York Evening World -- "Mark Twain Recalls Happy Days in Fresco" -- "Clemens briefly recalls 'dear, dead Bohemian days of long ago'"
New York World -- "Mark Twain Home, Captive of Little Girl" -- "Story devotes much space to young fellow-passenger Dorothy Quick"
New York World -- "My Hand Interviews with Mark Twain and Thomas Edison" -- "Clemens submits to having his palm read; in a mellow mood he comments on current situation and age"
New York Press -- "Mark Twain's Ideal Pipe" -- "Quoted from 'an interview the other day' seems genuine; not important but characteristic"
Great Thoughts -- "A Prince of Humorists" -- "Long with much padding, many passages that may well come from Mark Twain's writings and commentary"

Brooklyn Daily Eagle -- "Mark Twain on the Scope of the Children's Theater/What it Means to American Citizenship and Education" -- "Besides praising East Side theater for children, Clemens talks about the importance of enunciation, and of raising esthetic taste among immigrants; he also discourses on responsible citizenship vs. jingoistic patriotism
New York American, SUN, Times, World, Tribune -- "Rogers is Busted--Twain" -- "Clemens jokes broadly about supposed poverty of H.H. Rogers"

New York American, New York Herald, SUN, Times, World -- "Return from Bermuda/Mark Twain Faced Two Perils/Going to Make Less Noise/Mark Twain Gets a Sea Souse/Back from Bermuda with H.H. Rogers/Big Wave Loan to Rogers"
New York American -- "Twain Says He Told Her 'Book a Mistake Twain's Daughter Talks About Him'"
Boston Herald -- "Death of Roger/Mark Twain, Rockefeller, and Others Pay Tribute to Dead"
Baltimore News -- "Twain Puts Blame on the Typesetter"
Baltimore Star -- "Twain Pokes Fun at Union Station and Pities City
Baltimore American -- "Why Not Baltimore?"

New York American, Danbury News(?) -- "Mark Twain Has a Tobacco Heart/Mark Twain Cited for Awful Tobacco Habit/Mark Twain Smokes/The Psychology of the Tobacco Habit/Two Uncollected Twain Writings Found in British-Authored Books" -- "Clemens grumbles a little about interviewers but talks almost solely about his doctor's orders to reduce smoking and about the criticism of his having smoking while waiting for the Oxford ceremony"
New York World , New York Tribune -- "Samuel Clemens Interviews Himself at Clara's Wedding/Mark Twain Prepares Interview and Sketches Guest
The Lounger -- "Clara's Wedding"
New York American, SUN, Times, Tribune, Herald, World -- Mark Twain Returns from Bermuda"
New York Herald, SUN, Times, Tribune, Evening World -- "Mark Twain Leaves NYC for Bermuda" -- "Several brief indirect quotations on Clemens's health"
New York World -- "Mark Twain Returns Hastily to Bermuda" -- "Clemens Comments on his health and his solace in smoking cigars"

Human Life -- "Mark Twain Back in Feeble Health/Mark Twain at Bermuda/The Venerable Prince of Humorists Who Has Been Seeking Rest and Seclusion in the British Isles" -- "Mark Twain staying with the Allens; visitor is slow to get to main business and is gushy; nothing of consequence gets said, but this may be the last interview with a very sick man"

Chicago Inter-Ocean -- "Mark Twain's Boyhood (Jane Clemens)" -- "Mrs. Clemens lay the foundation for two legends about the boyhood of Clemens: his promises in the prescience of his father's coffin and his later promise never to drink intoxicants"
New York Evening Post , Parade Magazine -- "Mark Twain's Daughter"
